text: today's recipe is a rot asparagus and
pea salad from our June issue of Martha
Stewart Living just opening a pea pod so
you can see inside I think you've seen
these before these are the English or
garden peas not the sugar snap peas that
you eat the whole thing so you're going
to need to open them up and then remove
the peas from inside and for this recipe
we blanch the peas you just drop them in
a pot boiling water for like seconds
pull them out run them under cold water
to stop the cooking so that they start
looking like this and then they'll end
up looking like that which is basically
the same just a little bit more tender
and a little bit more bright green if
you don't have fresh peas on hand you
could actually use the frozen peas for
this recipe because these are blanched
just like frozen peas are for the
asparagus portion you'll need about 8
ounces of asparagus you want to trim off
any tough ends I like to break them if
I'm using them in a salad and they're
not going to be cooked so that I make
sure that I only get the most tender
parts normally if I'm cooking them I'll
just sort of line them up and cut off
where it seems to me that it'll become
tender but in an instance like this
where you're actually eating it raw and
there's nothing tenderizing it it's
pretty important that this part not
being there because this is really tough
and fibrous so get that off sometimes
you'll find though if your asparagus
isn't really tender like this one half
of it goes away but at least you know
you're not going to be eating something
unpleasant then what you do is once
they're snapped to the tender something
very thinly slice on a pretty sharp
diagonal this also ensures that your
asparagus will be nice and tender and
it's a really nice way to eat it when
it's raw like that
add the asparagus to one and a half cups
of blanched peas half a cup of toasted
chopped almonds really nicely toasted
and about a quarter cup of mint you can
tear the leaves if they're big or
coarsely chop them if you want to mint
is a great flavor pairing with both
asparagus and peas such a spring flavor
arrangement you think I think so you can
save a few cute and used for the top I
always like to do that make your food
look beautiful choose them with some
salt and pepper and then olive oil and
rice vinegar rice vinegar is a really
nice delicate flavor with these spring
ingredients you can use champagne
vinegar you can use white wine vinegar
too if you want whatever appeals to you
and what you have on hand you don't have
to necessarily go out and buy rice
vinegar if you don't have any but if you
do make sure that it's unseasoned rice
vinegar we're not using the seasoned
stuff here give it a toss my gosh I
could eat this whole bowl myself so
fresh okay this how it is done
think about that my gosh so beautiful
sometimes you put together some
ingredients and you think this is not
going to be amazing or it'll be good but
like unremarkable this is not one of
those times you put these together and
you think oh my gosh I can't believe
that those few simple ingredients came
together into something so delicious so
quickly
hmm crunchy nuts really make tough love
it
